sentence: S teady earnings are of key importance to income investors, since dividends are a distribution of a company's profits.
Here's a list of five Steady Eddies that meet IBD's top dividend stock criteria and have the most stable earnings in recent years.
All five earn a five-year Earnings Stability Factor of 1 on a scale from 0 (most stable) to 99 (most volatile).
Their yields also outpace the S&P 500's average 1.88% payout.
Two names from Friday's income column focusing on dividend stocks with high Relative Strength Ratings make this list too:Altria Group ( MO ) andReynolds American ( RAI ).
The tobacco companies currently pay $2.08 and $2.68 a share, respectively, on an annual basis, yielding 3.7% and 3.6%.
Altria's long-term dividend growth rate is 8% and Reynold's is 9%.
Paychex 's ( PAYX ) quarterly payout of 38 cents a share, or $1.52 annualized, works out to a 3.1% yield.
Its dividend growth rate is 6%, as is its five-year earnings growth rate.
The provider of payroll and employee benefits outsourcing services is expected to grow annual EPS 8% this year and 9% the next.
Colgate-Palmolive ( CL ), which also paid out 38 cents a share, or $1.52, has a 2.1% yield.
The consumer products giant has consistently paid dividends since 1895 and raised the payout each year for 52 years.
As such, it's a member of the S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats, which have boosted their dividend each year for at least the past 25 years.
Colgate's dividend growth rate is 9%, and its five-year earnings growth rate is 5%.
Home Depot ( HD ) rounds out the top five by yield.
It recently raised its quarterly dividend by 26% to 59 cents a share, or $2.36 for the full year, for a 2% payout.
Its dividend growth rate is tops of the five at 19%, and its five-year earnings growth rate is an impressive 23%.
Home Depot has benefited from an improving economy and housing market.
The stock's 93 RS Rating reflects a 9% advance so far this year.
That's on top of a 27% run-up last year.
